Nunc restat illud
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xx
etc. This is distinction 44 in which, after the Master determined about the power of God with respect to the quantity of things produced, here he treats about this same type of power with respect to the goodness of those things.

And it is divided into three parts because in the first place he asks whether God would be able to make a thing in a more perfect degree, in the second whether in a better mode, third whether everything that was possible always is possible a uniform state. The second begins at
post haec considerandum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. The third begins at
praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
.
The first is divided into two parts because in the first place he recites the error of some and recites the same, in the second place he determines and approves the truth, which begins at
verum hic ab eis
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
.

The third principal part, namely
praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx , is divided in three, for in the first place with respect to this question he considers a certain false opinion, in the second place he introduces his intention on the matter, in the third place he confirms his response. The second begins at
ad quod dicimus
Lombardus, I, d. xxx . The third begins at
fateamur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
etc.
Whether omnipotence is productively able to make some power dependent on it better or more perfect in being or to increase its perfection.

That not because anything dependent on God is infinitely perfect, therefore no such thing is able to become more perfect either in being or essentially. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because any individual thing of a superior species infinitely exceeds the perfection of the individual of an inferior species because the former exceeds through the entire breadth of species producible between itself and the other species. But these producible thing are infinite, therefore anything exceeding in this way is infinitely perfect.

In the second place, if something created were able to be made better in being it follows that this would be a being closer to the highest independent being than the previous. The consequent is false because any dependent thing is infinitely distant from God in terms of perfection, therefore not created this closer to him than any other. The consequence is clear because nearness to the highest being seems to be a part of the perfection of things.

In the third place, if God perfected man essentially, then either man would remain in the human species or not. Not the first because any specific perfection consists in something indivisible, just as the species of any number. But if the second option is granted then it follows that man is not improved in terms of perfection or essentially. The consequences is clear because from the fact that he ceased to be in the human species, he ceased to be a man, therefore the question is false.

In opposition is the
Master in the present distinction
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. And it is also proved by reason since to any finite perfect God is able to add some grade of perfection. But every thing dependent on God is of a finite perfection, therefore the question is true.

First conclusion: any species externally producible, just as it is of a limited perfection, so no such species exceeds another intrinsecally, quidditatively, or infinitely.
The first part is proved because, it this were the case, then it would follow that infinity would contain denominations of perfection absolutely. The consequent is false because then it would be God. And the consequence is clear because, if the opposite of the consequent were granted, it would follow that it is not intrinsically perfect absolutely and infinitely, which is the opposite of the antecedent. This is confirmed becase, just one intensively infinite thing does not exceed another intensively infinite thing, so perfectionally infinite thing does not exceed another perfectionally infinite thing. The second part is proved because the quiddity of any species is finite, therefore it only exceeds another finitely. The consequences is clear since what is exceeded is not greater than what is exceeding. The antecedent is clear because the quiddity of a thing is not greater than the intrinsic perfection of it is.

First corollary: though no species exceeds another absolutely infinitely, nevertheless the highest thing necessarily equally immeasurably exceeds anything created. This is clear because whatever it exceeds it exceeds completely since it is perfection, super simple, and indivisible, therefore.

Second corollary: though no two species are equally perfect absolutely, nevertheless the highest thing necessarily equally immeasurably exceeds any created species. Or said another way, though is more perfect than a donkey, nevertheless they are equally exceeded by God. The first is clear.

Third corollary: if some species were to contain infinite
individuals, it would not be on account of this that that it is more perfect then that it is now. Or the third corollary can be said thus, that any species of latitude beyond what is producible is comparable to another in any mode. This is clear because any finite thing is comparable to another finite thing in some mode.

Another corollary: it is both repugnant that two species are similarly equal in imperfection and it is repugnant that these be compared in some specific perfection. This is clear because whatever things are compared it is necessary that they be compared in some similar denomination of perfection which is common to each and predicable of each thing being compared because blackness is not able to be compared to whiteness in terms of blackness, but rather in terms of color according to which one of them is a more intense color, or a weaker, or a more perfect color than the other.

Second conclusion: though de facto some two species are immediate, nevertheless between any two species are infinite producible species. This is clear because between the human and angelic species there is de facto nothing in between. The second part is proved since the excess of one species over another is divisible, and consequently divisible according to an imaginable continuous quantity, and thus according to the points of this quantity there are more perfect producibile things and less perfect things, and since the points of this quantity are infinite, the proposed follows. The antecedent is clear because what is indivisible is not made better or more perfect

First corollary: that there are not more producible species are between God and non-degree than there are producible speces between man and the angels. This is clear because there are infinite producible in both cases.

The second corollary: just as the specific perfection or the perfection of a created entity does not apply precisely to the replication of the unity of the divine, so perfections of the species are not universally disposed or formed like the species of numbers. The first is clear because then it would follow that an angel would have greater perfection than understanding and willing. The consequent is false because there is nothing greater revealed in scripture. And the consequence is clear, the reason is because man has these perfections because man is able to understand and to will. The second part is proved because between the binary and tertiary there is no producible in between species, as there is between specific perfections.

Third corollary: just as any specific perfection consists in something indivisible really absolutely, so no superior species contains an inferior species formally. This is clear because such a perfection is punctual and just as when a unity is added or removed the species varies in number, so, according to the
Philosopher in VII of the Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysica, VII, xxx
, when some essential grade is added to something its definition and its perfection is changed. The second part is proved because, if this were true, then it would follow that man would formally a donkey. The consequence is clear because, according to the
Philosopher in VII of the Metaphysics ,
formal parts are predicate in direction from the defined
Aristoteles, Metaphysicase, VII, xxx . Again, it would follow that a donkey would formally be just and justice. This is clear having supposed that the whole perfection of a substance is above the whole perfection of an accident according to some.

Third conclusion: though no created thing remaining below the limits of its own species is able to be made better by God intrinsically essentially, nevertheless given any created thing God is able to make it better to produce something in it perfectionally better. The first part is proved because through the addition of any essential grade the specific perfection is changed. The antecedent is clear through what has been said since such perfections consists in something indivisible. For this reason
the Philosopher in book VIII of the Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae, VIII
compares in number the definition or perfection of a thing because, just as when unity is granted or removed from some number the species of the number changes, so having added or removed some essential grade the species of the thing or the definition is changed. The second is clear through what has been said because by any finite perfection God is able to produce something more perfect, therefore.

First corollary: though from omnipotence a supreme creatable thing is not able to be made,
nevertheless an infinite creatable thing is makeabl from itself. Each part is clear through
James of Viterbo in first quodlibet, question 2, article 1
Iacobus de Viterbo, Quodlibet, I, q. 2, a. 1
, where he indicates that a perfectional line of the universe through pure actuality according to what is above and pure potential according to what is below is terminated and there is some intermediate grade mixed from actuality and potentiality. From this it is clear that any grade between the first and the infinite more greatly ought to be called potentiality than actuality because it is closer to pure potentiality than to pure actuality, to God who is pure act.

Second corollary: though it would not be the case that two species would be equally perfect essentially, nevertheless it is repugnant that two species are accidentally equal. The first part is clear because these two species are not more different than two individuals of the same species and thus they are not two species but one. The second part is proved because whiteness is able to be of the same intension and extension as blackness, and consequently equal in this respect. From what has been said it is clear in what sense the question is able to be conceded and in what sense it is able to be denied.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued that any grade of perfection absolutely below the immeasured is communicable to a creature through participation, therefore some producible species is or is able to be of an infinite perfeciton. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because no great is repugnant to a creature, nor is one repugnant to another, since all concur at the same time in the divine essence, therefore nor is there repugnance on the part of communication because all things are communicated internally through his plenitude.

In the second place, God acts externally equally perfect as he does internally, therefore something external adequate to his power is able to correspond to him. The consequence is clear because what has an adequate term act this way internally.

In the third place, God begins to acquire a line of perfection absolutely, such that in the first proportional part of the hour he acquires so much perfection, and then in the second, etc. Then it follows that at the end of the hour the line will be completely acquired

In the fourth place against the first corollary, if this is the case, it follows that God would not be able to exceed a creature in terms of perfection. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because less excess does not introduce distance or make better. But through the corollary he exceeds indivisibly, therefore minimally.

In the fifth place against the last, the first necessary is changeable by creatuires in an infinity of ways, therefore two species are able to be equal in perfection. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because, just as God is mutable according to an imaginatry line ascending and descending different ( species, so also is he mutable according to the transversal line which is equally distant from him according to his every part. This is confirmed through
Alanus, in De maximis theologiae, rule 8 , where he says,
God is an intelligible sphere whose center is everywhere but whose circumference is nowhere
Alanus de Insulis .

Contra secundam conclusionem, infinitas mediorum simul non communicantium identitate speciei vel generis
non
tollit
finitatem
infinitatem finitatem
specificam extremorum ergo implicat inter duas species productas producibiles esse infinitas. Consequentia tenet quia ex opposito consequentis infertur oppositum antecedentis, et antecedens probatur quia implicat inter duos terminos finitos specifice esse infinita media specifice distincta.

Secundo contra secundum corollarium, est
Philosophus VIII Metaphysicae
ubi dicit quod
species sunt sicut numeri ergo perfectiones specificae formantur ad modum numerorum
Aristoteles, Metaphysica, VIII, xxx
. Item, Augustinus
amove a rebus numeros et nihil sunt.
Augustinus, xxx

Tertio contra idem, quia, si perfectiones specificae non attendentur penes replicationem unitatis divinae, hoc esset quia rationes constitutivae non possunt communicari aliis. Consequens est falsum quia rationale quae est ratio constitutiva
hominis communicatur angelis.

Quarto contra tertium corollarium, linea perfectionalis est divisibilis, ergo componitur ex divisibilibus, ergo quaelibet species est divisibilis quantitate, ergo non consistit in indivisibili, immo plura puncta correspondent ei ex quo habet divisibilem quantitatem.

Quinto contra idem quia illa species est aliquanta perfectio, ergo est quantitatis perfectionis, ergo habet latitudinem intensivam et consequenter ei correspondent plura puncta in linea perfectionis simplici.

Contra tertiam conclusionem: si secunda pars esset vera sequeretur quod imperfectionibus specificis creabilibus esset processus in infinitum. Consequens est falsum quia ibi est ordo essentialis in illis, igitur etc.
Secundo contra primum corollarium, aliqua dabilis species est certe perfectionis et aliqua in duplo maioris et aliqua in triplo, et sic in infinitum, ergo est dabilis infinitae perfectionis.

Tertio, linea perfectionis simpliciter incipit a non gradu et terminatur ad Deum, ergo est aliqua species ita proprie Deum sicut proprie non gradum. Patet consequentia ex quo sunt ibi duo extrema illam terminantia.

Quarto contra secundum corollarium, stat duo individua eiusdem speciei esse inaequaliter eiusdem perfectionis simpliciter, ergo stat duas species esse aequae perfectas essentialiter. Consequentia patet quia qualis est habitudo seu proportio individui unius speciei ad individuum alterius talis est habitudo speciei ad speciem. Antecedens est articulus: anima Christi est perfectior essentialiter anima, vide.

Quinto, aliqua duo entia genere differentia sunt aequaliter perfecta, ergo stat duas
species, etc.
species, etc.
Consequentia tenet quia quae differunt genere differunt species. Antecedens probatur de materia caeli et materia istorum inferiorum cum una sit transmutabilis generabilibus et corruptibilis, alia autem non sed quod sint aequae perfecte . Probatur quia utraque terminat inclusive totam latitudinem entis possibilis versus extremum inferius vel versus non gradu, ergo aequaliter distant a primo et summo terminante illam latitudinem seu lineam versus extremum superius.

Sexto, homo et anima sunt diversarum specierum et sunt eiusdem perfectionis essentialis vel aequalis, igitur. Antecedens probatur quia alia est ratio essentialis intrinseca animae et alia hominis, ut patet per earum diffinitiones quidditativas , homo enim dicitur substantia anima corporea rationalis anima vero in corporea. Sed secunda pars antecedentis probatur quia totum non est minus perfectum quam eius pars cum pars includatur in tota, ergo homo non est minus perfectus quam eius anima et maxime cum anima communicet corpori
corpori
omnem suam essentialem perfectionem et intrinsecam, sed quod anima non sit minus perfecta intrinsece quam compositum. Patet cum omnis perfectio essentialis ipsius compositi sit a forma quae dat sibi esse. Item, anima virtualiter et perfectiori modo continet omnem perfectionem compositi quam ipsum compositum, igitur aeque perfecta est intrinsece.

Ad primam, negatur antecedens sumendo ipsum collective et in sensu composito. Et cum probatur quia nullus gradus repugnat, etc. conceditur in sensu diviso quia nec a nec b nec c, tamen non sequitur propter hoc quod omnis possit simul esse et concurrere in eandem rem vel speciem quia talis gradus infinitus nec est nec esse potest.

Secundo, cum dicitur, quod non est repugnantia ex parte communicationis, etc., dicitur quod ex parte creaturae est incompossibilitas quia ei repugnat esse omnipotentem esse per se simpliciter esse necesse esse et independentem esse. Item, talis creatura
esset essentialiter iustitia cognitio gratia dilectio, et sic ipsa non posset decipi obliquae agere vel peccare, immo Deus eam non posset destruere et damnare. Patet ergo quod est repugnantia ex parte creaturae et ex parte talis denominationis cui repugnat communicari creaturae.

Ad secundam dicitur quod si li aeque perfecte notet vel respiciat agens. Conceditur antecedens, et negatur consequentia quia utrobique est Deus. Si vero denotet vel determinet termen actionis, negatur antecedens.

Et si arguitur Deus agit adextra secundum ultimum suae potentiae, ergo producit termen infinitum, hic respondetur quod si intelligatur quod non possit perfectius agere, negatur antecedens. Si autem intelligitur quod non potest perfectiori potentia vel modo agere, conceditur antecedens et negatur consequentia.

Ad tertiam, dicitur quod si casus sit possibilis in fine horae, nulla erit infinita, quamvis in infinitum aliqua sit perfecta, nulla tamen est illa secundum quod nulla est talis quae sit infinitae perfectionis. Et si dicitur quod ex omnibus istis Deus posset facere unam speciem quod si Deus faceret illa esset quia contineret omnia quae homo, sic in proposito, hic dicitur quod sic non posset fieri una ex omnibus istis quia nulla talis est creabilis seu possibilis.
Ad quartam, negatur consequentia. Ad probationem dicitur quamvis sit indivisibilis, tamen eminenter in ipso omne divisibile continetur, et ideo immense excedit.

Ad quintam, negatur consequentia et cum arguitur de linea transversali dicitur quod est imitabilis secundum lineam transversalem praecise secundum eandem rationem, sed secundum lineam rectam secundum aliam et aliam rationem, ita quod non secundum lineam transversalem est specierum perfectio mutanda seu imaginanda.

Ad sextam, dicitur quod Deus est sicut centrum cuiuslibet rei modo a centro circuli versus circumferentiam possunt infinitae lineae trahi aequaliter se habentes ad centrum quae forte differrent specie maxime ubi circulus esset compositus ex partibus diversarum rationum, sic de Deus et diversitate specierum potest imaginari.

Ad primam contra secundam conclusionem, dicitur quod ratio bene concluderet, si unum non includeret aliud formaliter vel aequivalenter sicut est in proposito quia species inferior includitur in superiori aequivalenter vel supereminenter, ideo argumentum non facit contra conclusionem.

Ad secundam dicitur quod, sicut compatitur secum multiplex etc. et ideo illam exponit
Aegidius Aegidius Romanos, xxx
primo sicut non inveniuntur duae species numerorum aeque distantes ab unitate nec duae species sic distantes etc. Secundo, sicut unitate dempta vel addita variatur species numerii sicut etc. Tertio, sicut binarius continetur virtualiter in ternario sic vege?num insensitivo et una species in aliam. Secundo, notandum secundum
Aegidium Aegidius Romanos, xxx
quod duplex est distantia una finita alia infinita. Prima est duplex quia quaedam est in qua cadit medium et alia in propria in qua in qua non potest esse medium ut punctalis. Infinita etiam est duplex quia quaedam est in qua quodlibet extremum dicit aliquam essentiam sicut Deus et creatura distant. Secunda in propria in qua unum termen extremum dicit essentiam et sic distant prima materia et nihil
et sic dicuntur distare infinite quia inter ipsa nulla est proportio et sic posset dici ad illud sapientiae omnia in numero pondere et mensura constituisti omnis entitas creatur in certo numero partium organicarum et partium eiusdem quantitatis et certi generis ac specie. Secundo, quod perfectiones et qualitates cuiuslibet entis sunt in certo numero. Item sicut in numero est aliqua species infima sic in speciebus. Item sicut numeri sunt immediati sic species sunt immediate de facto. Item impondere id est unicuique dedit proprias operationes
i
inclinationes a determinatos fines. Item, in mensura hoc est habent certum gradum perfectionis.

Ad aliam, dicitur quod Augustinus vult dicere quod
omnia formantur in certis partibus organicis et integralibus
Augustinus, xxx .

Ad tertiam, dicitur quod, si differentia sumitur pro primo modo dicendi per se et in quale, sic rationale dicitur differentia hominis. Si autem sumitur secundo modo ex hoc non distinguitur ab omni specie alterius generis, et sic non est rationale ultima differentia hominis quia convenit Deo et angelis. Si autem accipitur ut distinguitur ab omnibus quae sunt eiusdem generis sic est differentia hominis quia distinguit hominem ab omni
ee
alio quod continetur sub animali. Per hoc patet ad confirmationem.

Ad quartam, dicitur quod sicut trinarius est divisibilis, et tamen indivisibiliter est trinarius, ita species est divisibilis, et tamen stat in indivisibili ita quod illi gradus specifici sunt ut instans in tempore vel puncta in linea.

Ad quintum, dicitur quod quaelibet species est aliquanta perfectio quia eminenter continet perfectionem sub ipsa, non tamen sequitur quod habeat latitudinem intensivam formaliter sic quod ei correspondeat plura puncta sicut non sequitur binarius ut sic est quantitas discreta, ergo est divisibilis in binarios.
Ad primam contra tertiam conclusionem, potest concedi consequens quia in numeris videtur esse essentialis ordo et processus in infinitum.

Secundo, posset dici quod non oportet essentialem ordinem esse nisi in his quae actu sunt producta quia illa sunt tantum adinvicem comparabilia proprie quae habent realem et actualem entitatem modo species de facto productae sunt finitae, ideo inter illas stat ordo essentialis.
Ad secundam, dicitur quod in infinitum aliqua species est creata vel creabilis perfecta, et tamen nulla est perfecta in infinitum, ideo non potest dari species creata infinitae perfectionis.

Ad tertium, dicitur quod illa linea non terminatur ad Deum quia Deus est essentia non inclusa in illam lineam, sed totaliter extra illam immense illam excedens et quodlibet eius, sicut aeternitas tempus nec est imaginandum aliquid, ita prope Deum sicut prope non gradum.

Ad quartam, quidquid sit de consequentia, negatur antecedens. Ad articulum dicitur quod intelligitur de dispositionibus naturalibus et habitibus animam Christi informantibus quae perficiunt et meliorant essentiam animae.
Ad quintam, negatur antecedens. Ad probationem dicitur quod posset esse dubium, utrum sit materia ibi.
Secundo, posset dici quod licet ibi esset materia, non tamen eiusdem speciei cum materia istorum inferiorum.
Tertio, dicitur quod, si sic materia utrobique quod ambae sunt transmutabiles quantum est ex parte sui.
Quarto, diceretur quod si essent diversarum specierum altera non terminaret totam latitudinem entis creabilis, immo eis corresponderent diversa puncta in linea perfectionis.

Ad sextam,
primo dicitur quod anima non communicat corpori quodlibet suum esse perfectum perfectione simpliciter quia anima est formaliter vita, formaliter indivisibilis, formaliter forma intellectiva, unde principium modus et constat quod nullum istorum formaliter communicat corpori seu homini cum homo non sit formaliter vita nec intellectus.

Secundo, dicitur quod quaedam sunt species compositae quaedam simplices modo speciei compositae in linea perfectionis simpliciter correspondent duo puncta secundum formam unus et secundum formam alius, ideo licet una species sit, tamen possunt dici duae secundum quid. Ex quo patet quod homo est perfectior anima saltim extensiva perfectione.

Tertio, posset dici quod corollarium intelligitur de speciebus simplicibus quibus correspondet unus punctus in linea perfectionem simpliciter vel intelligitur de speciebus totaliter distinctis quarum una non includitur in altera ut pars eius.
Ad rationes in oppositum, patet per dicta in corollariis quid dicendum sit et in conclusionibus ac argumentorum solutionibus.

Notandum tamen gratia materiae quod duplex est accessus sive appropinquatio creaturae ad summum una est extrinseca illius perfectionis et illa mensuratur penes distantia quae est inter illam perfectionem et Deum et quia quaelibet distantia inter Deum et creaturam est infinita, ideo accessus creturae ad Deum non mensuratur penes talem distantiam extrinsecam. Alia est distantia intrinseca creaturae et illa est inter illam perfectionem specificam et non gradum perfectionis simpliciter quia quaelibet superior continet eminenter totam latitudinem perfectionum inferiorum et illa magis proprie vocatur accessus ad summum quam alia prima quae est extrinseca creatura.

Secundo, notandum quod accessus ad summum isto modo est acquisitio divinae participationis et quanto talis participatio. Maior est tanto est creatura perfectior nec ideo quia creatura est similior Deo magis participat divinam bonitatem, sed econverso quia magis participat divinam bonitatem, ideo est similior sibi quia fundamentum prius est suo relativo et causa suo effectu.

Item, quanto creatura illam plus participat tanto plus Deum imitatur et sic idem est accessus creaturae ad Deum et recessus a non gradu, licet perfectio specifica per accessum ad summum magis proprie mensuretur quam per recessum a non gradu quia ut est accessus dicit quam positivum et ut est recessus privativum.

Nunc illud restat
Lombardus, I, d. xxx
etc. Prima conclusio: quod Deus potest alia facere quam facit et quae facit posset meliora facere unde Deus potuisset talem fecisse hominem qui nec posset peccare nec vellet, et si talem fecisset meliorem quam fecerit fecisset.

Secunda conclusio: quod Deus eorum quae facit quaedam posset facere modo meliori et quaedam modo minus bono quam faciat ut li aliter seu alter modus referatur ad qualitatem creaturae non ad sapientiam conditoris, non enim meliori nec minus bona sapientia posset facere quae facit quam de facto faciat.

Tertia conclusio: quod Deus potest quidquid semel potuit et semper vult quidquid semel voluit id est eam habet potentiam et voluntatem quam semel habuit unde potuit in
incarnari est incarnatus eadem potentia, sicut eadem est scientia qua scivit se resurrecturum et sic se resurrexisse, non tamen potest facere omne illud semper quod aliquando potuit nec vult esse vel fieri, sed fuisse vel factum esse ita et de scientia dicendum est eodem modo conformiter.
